intro: Malleastrum gracile subsp. emarginatum, commonly known as the narrow-leaf malleastrum, is a low-growing shrub native to South America. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae, which includes plants known for their distinctive leaf structures and sometimes edible parts. The subspecies is characterized by its slender, often hairy stems and narrow, lanceolate leaves with a slightly notched base. It typically thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is found in coastal and mountainous regions. This plant is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and ecological adaptations.
